questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard along the lower left sternal border. The murmur decreases in intensity on rapid squatting and increases in intensity when he performs the Valsalva maneuver. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiodysplasia can be associated with aortic stenosis. While aortic stenosis may also manifest with a systolic murmur, the murmur would decrease with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload) and increase with rapid squatting (increased preload). Moreover, aortic stenosis usually presents later in life.

B) INCORRECT:

Predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) or congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, systolic murmurs caused by valvular disease or congenital heart disease generally demonstrate increased intensity with rapid squatting (increased preload) and decreased intensity with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload).

C) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur caused by subvalvular dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO). Rapid squatting increases left ventricular preload, decreasing the dynamic LVOTO and softening the intensity of the murmur, whereas the Valsalva maneuver decreases preload, which exacerbates dynamic obstruction and makes the murmur louder. Unlike a murmur due to valvular or supravalvular aortic stenosis, which is best heard at the right upper sternal border, the systolic ejection murmur due to HCM is best heard at the left lower sternal border and/or Erb's point (cardiology). Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. Since HCM is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes, patients with HCM should be advised to avoid strenuous sports. Those at particularly high risk (e.g., survived a previous arrhythmia) should undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

D) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism can be associated with atrial septal defects (ASD) or ventricular septal defects (VSD). An ASD can present with a systolic murmur, but it would likely also show fixed splitting of the S2. A VSD can present with a holosystolic (not systolic ejection) murmur. The intensity of both defects would decrease rather than increase with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload) and increase with rapid squatting (increased preload).

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary apoplexy can occur in mitral stenosis, which presents with a diastolic murmur heard in the third left intercostal space but not a systolic murmur.

F) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms may be associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation may present with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. If the intensity changes at all, it would decrease with the Valsalva maneuver and/or increase with rapid squatting. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.
questions.hint: Echocardiography would most likely show asymmetric interventricular septal hypertrophy and/or systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, which are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after collapsing while playing basketball. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. On arrival, there is no palpable pulse and no respiratory effort is seen. He is declared dead. The family agrees to an autopsy. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects are relatively common with approx. 2/1000 live births and can lead to congestive heart failure and arrhythmias if left untreated. However, symptoms usually manifest later on in life, and sudden cardiac death in a previously asymptomatic patient is very unlikely.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism is often triggered by physical exercise/strain. Although a large pulmonary embolism can lead to shock with circulatory collapse and sudden death, risk factors such as immobility and hypercoagulability or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis are usually present. While the diagnosis cannot be definitively excluded here, a different cause of death is more likely in a young athlete.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac myxoid tumors (e.g., atrial myxomas) most commonly occur in the left heart and can cause obstruction and damage to the mitral valve. While congestive heart failure and rarely sudden cardiac death can occur in untreated patients, symptoms such as weight loss, pallor, dyspnea on exertion, and palpitations are more common. Additionally, cardiac myxomas most frequently occur in adults between 40–60 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Postductal narrowing of the aorta would be present in a patient with coarctation of the aorta. Although coarctation of the aorta can very rarely lead to sudden cardiac death, patients more typically present with hypertension in the upper extremities as well as hypotension and claudication of the lower extremities. Sudden death in a previously asymptomatic patient would be unlikely.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

E) INCORRECT:

An enlarged descending aorta would be present in a patient with a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA), which can lead to sudden death if it ruptures (or even more rarely if it dissects). However, generally rupture or dissection in a nontraumatic setting will be preceded by at least a short period of severe chest and/or back pain before collapse. Additionally, TAAs are usually found in older adults. They can occur in young patients, but mainly in those with connective tissue diseases (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and occur most commonly in the ascending aorta. This patient has no positive family or personal history nor specific signs to suspect these conditions, such as long fingers, hyperextensible joints, or hyperelastic skin. This combination of factors means that this finding is less likely the cause of his sudden death.

F) INCORRECT:

Atheromatous plaque rupture would be seen in a patient with myocardial infarction (MI). Although MI is a common cause of sudden cardiac death, MI due to arteriosclerosis is rare in young patients unless they have a hereditary condition such as familial hypercholesterolemia. This patient has no family or personal history of serious illness so that a congenital lipid disorder is unlikely.
Image Description:

In stable plaques, the lipid pool is surrounded by a thick fibrous cap and leads to extensive narrowing of the arterial lumen. In vulnerable plaques, the lipid pool is surrounded by a thin fibrous cap and minimally narrows the arterial lumen.

G) CORRECT:

Interventricular septal hypertrophy is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy and is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in athletes under the age of 30. The condition is often asymptomatic but can cause life-threatening arrhythmias and sudden death. A systolic ejection murmur that increases with valsalva maneuver and standing and decreases with hand grip, squatting, or lying down can be an important clue toward the diagnosis.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

H) INCORRECT:

A pericardial fluid collection (pericardial effusion) can lead to pericardial tamponade. While pericardial tamponade can cause cardiogenic shock and subsequent death, especially if the fluid accumulates quickly, other symptoms such as chest pain and dyspnea usually precede a collapse. Furthermore, this patient has no history of chest trauma or conditions such as pericarditis, which are commonly associated with pericardial tamponade.
Image Description:

Photograph of a heart at autopsy (close-up of the left ventricle in longitudinal section)

There is coagulated, brown blood in the opened pericardium.

Coagulation indicates previous hemorrhage from the heart chambers into the pericardium. The coagulated blood compresses the heart (pericardial tamponade), leading to cardiac arrest.
questions.hint: This patient likely had a left ventricular outflow tract obstruction that was exacerbated by exercise.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend after briefly losing consciousness. He passed out while moving furniture into her apartment. She said that he was unresponsive for a minute but regained consciousness and was not confused. The patient did not have any chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing before or after the episode. He has had episodes of dizziness when exercising at the gym. His blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg while supine and 120/70 mm Hg while standing. Pulse is 70/min while supine and 75/min while standing. On examination, there is a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a systolic murmur at the apex, both of which disappear with passive leg elevation. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A prolonged QT interval may be congenital or acquired. It typically remains asymptomatic until patients present with syncope, seizures, or life-threatening arrhythmias. Syncope in young patients should raise suspicion of a congenital long QT syndrome. However, these syndromes would not account for the murmurs in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common hereditary heart disease and may be obstructive or non-obstructive. HCM may be asymptomatic or manifest with exertional dyspnea, syncope (as in this patient), cardiac arrhythmias, heart murmurs, or sudden cardiac death (particularly during or after intense physical activity). As is the case here, HCM is typically associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease left ventricular filling (Valsalva maneuver and standing) and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular filling (squatting or passive leg elevation). Patients with HCM may also have an accompanying murmur of mitral regurgitation (i.e., a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex), which is caused by systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (SAM) leaflets into the left ventricular outflow tract.

Echocardiography is the best initial and confirmatory test.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

While a bicuspid aortic valve is associated with early-onset aortic stenosis, which would cause a systolic murmur, maneuvers that increase venous return like passive elevation of the legs would increase the intensity of this murmur. Furthermore, an aortic stenosis murmur is best heard at the right upper sternal border.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the most common heart valve abnormality and the most common cause of mitral regurgitation (MR). MVP is typically associated with a mid-to-late systolic crescendo murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. As in this patient, maneuvers that increase ventricular volumes (e.g., passive leg elevation) will cause the murmur typical of MVP to diminish or be delayed. Passive leg elevation results in increased right ventricular volume, right ventricular output, and, subsequently, increased left ventricular volume. However, the murmur in MVP is also associated with a midsystolic click, which is absent in this patient. Furthermore, syncope does not typically occur in MVP.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension occurs as a result of hypovolemia (dehydration, hemorrhage, or use of diuretics), insufficient counterregulation due to autonomic dysfunction, or as a side effect of medication (vasodilators). This patient has no significant changes in hemodynamics on standing, and his murmurs would not be explained by orthostatic hypotension, making this choice unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Vasovagal syncope is neurally-mediated syncope caused by parasympathetic hyperactivity and/or sympathetic hypoactivity, leading to bradycardia and/or vasodilation. These physiologic responses lead to a decrease in blood pressure and cerebral perfusion. It is usually triggered by prolonged standing, emotional stress, or painful stimuli, none of which is part of this patient's history. Furthermore, vasovagal syncope would not explain the murmurs seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Carotid sinus syndrome can cause neurally-mediated syncope due to hypersensitivity of the afferent or efferent limbs of the carotid sinus reflex arc. This results in bradycardia and/or vasodilation. Syncope is often triggered when pressure is applied to the carotid sinus. This patient's history of passing out while moving furniture is not consistent with this diagnosis. Furthermore, carotid sinus syndrome cannot explain the murmurs in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve stenosis (MVS) can also present with exertional dizziness. However, MVS causes a delayed, decrescendo diastolic murmur that is best heard at the cardiac apex. Unlike this patient's cardiac murmur, the murmur of MVS would increase with maneuvers that increase venous return and cardiac preload.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: The patient is likely to have a family history of a close relative that passed away unexpectedly at a young age.

questions.text: A previously healthy 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of an episode of unconsciousness that suddenly happened while playing football 30 minutes ago. He was not shaking and regained consciousness after about 30 seconds. Over the past three months, the patient has had several episodes of shortness of breath while exercising as well as sensations of a racing heart. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. Cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur that increases with valsalva maneuver and standing and an S4 gallop. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a deep S wave in lead V1 and tall R waves in leads V5 and V6. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Abnormal movement of the mitral valve

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the most likely cause of this patient's presentation, can be confirmed by echocardiography which typically shows systolic anterior motion of the anterior mitral valve leaflet, asymmetrical septal hypertrophy, and septal wall thickness of >15 mm. Doppler echocardiography can reveal increased left ventricular outflow tract pressure gradients.
Image Description:

Transthoracic echocardiogram (apical three-chamber view)

The walls of the left ventricle are asymmetrically hypertrophied. Compared to normal findings (green dashed outline), the interventricular septum (red overlay) is markedly thickened (green arrows). The lateral wall is also thickened, but not to the same extent as the interventricular septum.

These findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. To assess for left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction, the LVOT pressure gradient during systole should be measured.

LW: lateral wall; LV: left ventricle; IVS: interventricular septum; MV: mitral valve; AV: aortic valve; LA: left atrium

B) INCORRECT:

Symmetric left ventricular (LV) wall thickening can be seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM) which may manifest with palpitation, dyspnea, and syncope. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of RCM such as orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, increased jugular venous pressure, and peripheral edema. Furthermore, this patient's presentation and ECG findings are more suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which manifests with asymmetrical LV wall thickening.

C) INCORRECT:

Bicuspid aortic valve is the most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in patients younger than 70. AS may present with exertional dyspnea, syncope, and S4 gallop. However, unlike the murmur in this patient, AS typically presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that decreases in intensity with valsalva maneuver and standing.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur with an ejection click

In aortic stenosis, there is usually radiation into the carotids.

D) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) can be congenital or acquired (following acute myocardial infarction). Unlike the murmur in this patient, VSD typically produces a harsh holosystolic murmur that decreases in intensity with valsalva maneuver and standing, and S4 gallop does not usually occur. Furthermore, VSD would be unlikely in this previously healthy patient with no history of recent myocardial infarction.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve leaflet thickness ≥ 5 mm is seen in the classical form of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). While MVP is typically asymptomatic, symptoms such as dyspnea, syncope, and palpitation may present with MVP complications (e.g., arrhythmias). However, unlike the auscultatory findings in this patient, MVP typically presents with a midsystolic click followed by mid-to-late systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur. Additionally, S3 gallop (rather than S4 gallop) may be heard in severe cases.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

F) INCORRECT:

Reduced left ventricular ejection fraction can be seen in dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) which may present with palpitation, exertional dyspnea, and syncope. However, the auscultatory findings in DCM include S3 gallop (rather than S4 gallop) and holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla (i.e., mitral valve regurgitation due to the progressive ventricular dilation).
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)
questions.hint: This previously healthy patient presents with exertional dyspnea, syncope, palpitations, and a systolic ejection murmur that increases upon standing and the valsalva maneuver. Additionally, his S4 gallop and ECG findings indicate left ventricular hypertrophy. These features are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the physician 1 hour after passing out at home. Her husband reports that she suddenly lost consciousness for approximately 30 seconds while shoveling snow in the driveway. Immediately before the episode, she felt light-headed and short of breath. Two months ago, she experienced a similar episode while running in her yard with her children. She has no history of serious illness. Her father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 44 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur best heard along the left sternal border that decreases with hand grip. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ramipril is an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor. One of the major effects of these medications is to decrease afterload. In patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, this would result in a detrimental increase in the pressure gradient across the left ventricular outflow tract. Because this would cause this patient's symptoms to worsen, this drug is contraindicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Septal myectomy is an effective treatment for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and leads to decreased left ventricular outflow tract pressure gradient, decreased symptom frequency, and increased exercise tolerance. The best results have been observed in young, healthy patients without other cardiac risk factors, such as this patient. However, due to the invasive nature of the procedure, it is reserved for patients who are refractory to maximal medical therapy. It would therefore not be the most appropriate treatment at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil and other nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are useful agents but are considered a second-line treatment for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This class of drugs provides heart rate control, permitting longer diastole and increased diastolic filling.

D) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. Administration of this medication results in peripheral vasodilation (decreased afterload), which would result in a detrimental increase in the pressure gradient across the left ventricular outflow tract. For this reason, amlodipine is contraindicated in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Placement of a cardiac pacemaker may be considered in symptomatic patients with medical treatment-refractory hypertrophic cardiomyopathy who are not candidates for septal myectomy and/or have a clinical indication for permanent pacing. Because this patient has not received first-line treatment, cardiac pacing is not appropriate at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Radiofrequency ablation is an option for treating recalcitrant atrial fibrillation, which is a complication in a minority of patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. There is no evidence that this patient is suffering from atrial fibrillation. Moreover, ablation of the arrhythmogenic focus would be appropriate only after attempting medical therapy (such as rate/rhythm control and anticoagulation).

G) CORRECT:

Metoprolol and other beta blockers are first-line agents for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Beta blockers provide rate control, which allows for a longer diastole and greater diastolic filling. In addition, these drugs reduce contractile force, which leads to a reduced left ventricular outflow tract pressure gradient and reduced myocardial oxygen demand. Furthermore, refraining from intense physical exercise is indicated in all patients with this condition, even those receiving pharmacotherapy, because of the increased risk of sudden cardiac death. Primary prophylactic ICD placement should be considered in patients with a family history of HCM-related sudden cardiac death and/or syncope.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: This patient presents with exertional syncope, a systolic ejection murmur that decreases with increased systemic vascular resistance (hand grip), and a family history of sudden cardiac death. In a young adult with no history of hypertension or other cardiac risk factors, this should raise concern for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath. She is now unable to jog for more than 10 minutes without stopping to catch her breath. Cardiac examination shows a harsh systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. The murmur increases in intensity when she moves from a squatting to a standing position and decreases when she clenches her fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dystrophin defects are responsible for Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy. Patients with dilated cardiomyopathy can present with exertional dyspnea and a systolic mitral regurgitation (MR) murmur. However, an MR murmur would be heard loudest at the 5th left intercostal space in the midclavicular line (mitral region), and increase in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., hand clenching). Moreover, DMD would cause rapidly progressive muscle weakness with an onset during childhood, and female individuals are very rarely affected by this X-linked recessive condition.

B) INCORRECT:

A fibrillin-1 defect is the cause of Marfan syndrome, which can result in mitral valve prolapse (MVP), aortic aneurysms, and/or aortic dissections. Severe MVP can cause exertional dyspnea and a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., standing up suddenly) and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., hand clenching). However, the murmur would be heard loudest at the 5th left intercostal space in the midclavicular line (mitral region) and would typically be preceded by a midsystolic click. Also, this patient does not have any marfanoid features (e.g., arachnodactyly, tall stature, long extremities, hypermobile joints).

C) CORRECT:

Mutations in the cardiac beta-myosin heavy chain gene cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is the most common hereditary cardiomyopathy. The mode of inheritance is typically autosomal dominant. Echocardiography (or examination of an autopsy specimen) would most likely demonstrate concentric left ventricular hypertrophy or hypertrophy of the interventricular septum. Microscopic analysis will show hypertrophic myocytes with disoriented myofibrils (myofibrillar disarray).

All symptomatic patients should receive a beta blocker and be considered for an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) if there is a risk of sudden death. Positive inotropic and afterload-reducing or preload-reducing drugs (e.g., digitalis, glyceryl trinitrate, calcium channel blockers of the dihydropyridine class, ACE inhibitors) are contraindicated in cases of obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. If symptoms persist, myectomy or transcoronary ablation of septal hypertrophy are further treatment options.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

GAA trinucleotide repeats within the frataxin gene on chromosome 9 result in Friedreich ataxia, which is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Friedreich ataxia would also manifest with impaired muscle coordination, deformities due to muscle spasticity (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, pes cavus), hearing loss, visual impairment, and/or diabetes mellitus. The absence of these features makes a GAA trinucleotide repeat disorder unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Myocyte ion channel defects are responsible for several inherited long QT syndromes (e.g., Romano-Ward syndrome, Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome), which manifest as acute episodes of palpitations and/or syncope (due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias). The auscultatory findings in this patient suggest LVOT obstruction, which is not caused by myocyte ion channel defects.

F) INCORRECT:

CTG trinucleotide repeats within the DMPK gene result in myotonic dystrophy. The typical cardiac manifestations in this condition are conduction blocks and/or tachyarrhythmias. Also, myotonic dystrophy is associated with other features such as progressive muscle weakness, myotonia, frontal balding, and/or visual impairment (due to cataracts), none of which are seen here.

G) INCORRECT:

A deletion in chromosome 7q occurs in Williams syndrome, which is associated with left ventricular outflow obstruction due to supravalvular aortic stenosis. Clinically, this can present with exertional dyspnea and a systolic murmur that decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., fist clenching). However, a murmur due to aortic stenosis is best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (aortic area), and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., standing up suddenly). Moreover, this patient does not have other findings indicative of Williams syndrome, such as elfin facies and mental disabilities.
questions.hint: A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border indicates left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. This patient's LVOT obstruction is dynamic, i.e., it increases with maneuvers that decrease venous return (standing from squatting) and decreases with maneuvers that increase afterload (clenching fists). This finding suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A previously healthy 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is attempted for 10 minutes without success. An autopsy is performed one hour after the death of the patient. During the autopsy, examination of the heart shows pliable valves without any calcification. A photograph of sections of the heart obtained at autopsy is shown. The patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathophysiologic changes?

choices.text: Decreased duration of the myocardial action potential
Fixed obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract
Marked noncompliance of the left ventricular wall
Severe narrowing of the left anterior descending artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Significantly reduced duration of myocardial action potential (due to a defect in the voltage-gated sodium channel) is a pathophysiologic change in Brugada syndrome, an important cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. However, Brugada syndrome would not be associated with ventricular hypertrophy, which is seen in the photograph. In patients with ventricular hypertrophy, an increase in the duration of the myocardial depolarization would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Significantly reduced myocardial contraction force (systolic dysfunction) is seen in dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), which can cause sudden cardiac death. However, DCM more commonly presents with palpitations, exertional dyspnea, and/or features of congestive heart failure. A gross pathology specimen of DCM shows dilated cardiac chambers with thinned ventricular walls as opposed to the severe hypertrophy of the left ventricle seen here. In this patient's condition, a reduction in myocardial contraction force would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract is caused by aortic stenosis (AS), which can cause sudden cardiac death in severe cases. AS can manifest in young adults as a result of calcification of a congenital bicuspid valve (in high-income countries) or as a sequela to rheumatic heart disease (in low-income countries). However, patients with severe AS typically experience syncope, angina, and dyspnea. This man was previously healthy; in a young, asymptomatic individual with pliable, noncalcified heart valves, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a more likely cause of sudden cardiac death. Unlike AS, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes dynamic (not fixed) left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

D) CORRECT:

Marked reduction in compliance (physiology) of the left ventricular wall and reduced chamber volume due to left ventricular hypertrophy are key features of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). These changes prevent ventricular relaxation and decrease the volume of blood that enters the left ventricle during diastole (diastolic dysfunction). The morphology of LV hypertrophy in HCM is highly variable; patients typically develop asymmetrical septal hypertrophy but some patients develop symmetric, concentric LV hypertrophy, as seen here, or apical LV hypertrophy. Interventricular septum hypertrophy may narrow the left ventricular outflow tract, which increases the velocity of blood flowing past it and decreases pressure (Venturi effect). This pulls the mitral valve leaflet down during systole (systolic anterior motion) instead of allowing it to snap shut, which causes dynamic left ventricular outflow obstruction, mitral regurgitation, and, in severe cases, hemodynamic collapse and death.

Chamber noncompliance is also seen in cases of restrictive cardiomyopathy; however, this condition is not commonly associated with sudden cardiac death or severe thickening of the left ventricle.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe narrowing (≥ 90% stenosis) of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) can cause myocardial infarction (MI), which is an important cause of sudden cardiac death. Since the earliest gross changes of MI (e.g., a dark mottling) are only seen 12 hours after death, an MI cannot be ruled out from the specimen in the photograph, which was obtained one hour after the pateint's death. This patient's condition, i.e., hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), can result in MI due to increased oxygen demand in the hypertrophied ventricle and impaired coronary vessel perfusion (due to impaired ventricular diastole and obstruction of blood flow to the aorta), but HCM is not associated with narrowing of the large coronary arteries such as the LAD. Instead, severe narrowing of the large coronary arteries is a feature of atherosclerotic disease, which would not be expected in this young patient.
questions.hint: The severe hypertrophy of the left ventricle seen in the autopsy images of this young man who died of sudden cardiac death confirms a diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after collapsing while playing basketball. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, there is no palpable pulse or respiratory effort observed. He is declared dead. The family agrees to an autopsy. Cardiac workup prior to this patient's death would most likely have shown which of the following findings?

choices.text: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
Narrowing of the left main coronary artery
Symmetric thickening of the left ventricle
Increased mean pressure gradient across the aortic valve

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most likely cause of this young patient's death is sudden cardiac arrest due to hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The diagnosis can be confirmed by echocardiography, which typically shows systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, asymmetrical septal hypertrophy, and a septal wall thickness of >15 mm. Doppler studies show increased left ventricular outflow tract pressure gradients.
Image Description:

Transthoracic echocardiogram (apical three-chamber view)

The walls of the left ventricle are asymmetrically hypertrophied. Compared to normal findings (green dashed outline), the interventricular septum (red overlay) is markedly thickened (green arrows). The lateral wall is also thickened, but not to the same extent as the interventricular septum.

These findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. To assess for left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction, the LVOT pressure gradient during systole should be measured.

LW: lateral wall; LV: left ventricle; IVS: interventricular septum; MV: mitral valve; AV: aortic valve; LA: left atrium

B) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the left main coronary artery is seen in coronary artery disease (CAD). CAD is a chronic disease process that typically manifests in older individuals with exertional angina or dyspnea. Patients with severe CAD can present with cardiac arrest due to myocardial ischemia. However, this patient has no known history of angina, and the sudden collapse of a young patient with no other history of symptoms makes a diagnosis of premature, severe CAD very unlikely.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD), like any structural heart defect, increases the risk of sudden cardiac death. While small defects are usually asymptomatic (and mostly benign), larger defects can lead to myocardial remodeling, Eisenmenger syndrome, and heart failure. The absence of any symptoms or medical problems prior to this patient's collapse makes VSD an unlikely cause of death in this case.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

D) INCORRECT:

Symmetric thickening of the left ventricle is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM). It is often the result of chronic illness that leads to decreased elasticity of the heart (e.g., amyloidosis, hemochromatosis), which, in the long run, can lead to sudden cardiac death. However, prior to such an event, patients typically present with a long-standing history of palpitations, dyspnea, and syncope. Sudden cardiac arrest in a young patient is better explained by a condition that classically manifests with asymmetrical septal hypertrophy and can become symptomatic at any age.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased mean pressure gradient across the aortic valve is seen in aortic stenosis (AS), which can manifest with syncope and cardiac death. However, patients usually present at older ages with exertional dyspnea and, depending on the severity of the stenosis, syncope. The age of presentation is typically older than 70 years in degenerative calcific aortic stenosis and older than 40 in congenital bicuspid aortic valves. Without any prior symptomatic history, sudden cardiac death secondary to severe aortic stenosis is very unlikely. Sudden cardiac arrest in a young patient is better explained by a condition that classically manifests with asymmetrical septal hypertrophy causing increased left ventricular outflow tract pressure gradients below (not across) the level of the aortic valve.
questions.hint: This patient likely had a left ventricular outflow tract obstruction and fatal arrhythmia that was exacerbated by exercise.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Cardiovascular exam shows the point of maximal impulse to be in the mid-axillary line. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with a normal right ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's ventricular hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of glycogen is seen in type 2 glycogen storage disease (Pompe disease). Clinical features include generalized muscle weakness, hyperlipidemia, hypoglycemia, and ketosis, none of which are present in this patient. In addition, Pompe disease usually manifests in newborns, and death occurs within weeks of birth.

B) INCORRECT:

The accumulation of protein fibrils within the myocardium is seen in amyloidosis. Amyloidosis is caused by misfolded proteins, which are most commonly derived from immunoglobulin light chain, amyloid precursor protein, and serum amyloid A. Amyloidosis results in thickening of the myocardium, as in this patient. However, the myocardial thickening in amyloidosis is usually biventricular.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposition of endomyocardial collagen is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy. It is caused by proliferation of connective tissue, which results in decreased elasticity of the myocardium and severe diastolic dysfunction. Although restrictive cardiomyopathy can cause atrial enlargement, it is commonly due to dilation, not hypertrophy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's LVH is due to accumulation of sarcomeres in parallel, likely caused by chronic hypertension (increased afterload). Chronic hypertension increases myocardial wall tension, which leads to changes in gene expression and subsequent duplication of sarcomeres in parallel and diastolic dysfunction. In contrast, left ventricular dilation is caused by the accumulation of sarcomeres in series, which results in systolic dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of T lymphocytes is seen in acute myocarditis. Clinical features of myocarditis include flu-like symptoms, dyspnea, chest pain, arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock, all of which this patient lacks. In addition, echocardiography in myocarditis is usually unremarkable but can show ventricular dilation, diffuse hypokinesia, reduced ejection fraction, impaired contractility, and regional wall motion abnormalities.
questions.hint: This patient's left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) is due to a chronic increase in afterload.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing during soccer practice. His father died of sudden cardiac arrest at the age of 36 years. The patient appears well. His pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows large R waves in the lateral leads and deep S waves in V1 and V2. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
Video

choices.text: Monoclonal light chain deposition in the myocardium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monoclonal light chain deposition in the myocardium occurs in cardiac amyloidosis, which is secondary to primary (AL) amyloidosis, and leads to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. Patients can also present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, and ECG may show a pseudoinfarct pattern that is similar to the repolarization abnormalities seen here. However, this plasma cell dyscrasia typically affects individuals ≥ 40 years of age, and patients are likely to have symptoms of heart failure as well as other systemic manifestations.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilatation of the aortic root occurs in patients with connective tissue syndromes (e.g., Marfan syndrome), a bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension, atherosclerosis, aortic dissection, and aortic stenosis. Significant dilatation of the aortic annulus can lead to aortic regurgitation, which results in a decrescendo diastolic murmur, in contrast to this patient's systolic ejection murmur. Furthermore, this patient's condition is not associated with aortic root dilation.

C) INCORRECT:

Significant dilatation of the left ventricle is characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy. While patients with dilated cardiomyopathy may present with exertional dyspnea from heart failure, they are less likely to experience exertional syncope. ECG findings in dilated cardiomyopathy include first-degree AV block, left bundle branch block, left anterior fascicular block, and other intraventricular conduction abnormalities, or evidence of prior infarction as the underlying cause; none of these findings are seen in this case. Examination may reveal a pansystolic murmur of secondary mitral regurgitation heard best at the apex due to LV dilatation, whereas this patient has a prominent systolic ejection murmur.

D) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) manifests with an area of increased left ventricular wall thickness that is typically asymmetrical and involves the septum or anterolateral LV wall. Along with mitral valve and papillary muscle abnormalities, septal hypertrophy can lead to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, resulting in exertional syncope and a systolic ejection murmur. Although the systolic murmur in patients with HCM does not significantly radiate into the carotid arteries, left ventricular outflow tract obstruction in obstructive HCM may mimic an aortic stenosis murmur and may be heard as a subtle ejection murmur on auscultation of the carotids. The ECG shows high voltage QRS complexes, indicating left ventricular hypertrophy. HCM is most commonly a hereditary condition, which explains the history of sudden cardiac death in this patient's father.

The intensity of the murmur associated with HCM decreases with maneuvers that increase venous return (e.g., rapid squatting) because they increase preload, which in turn decreases the pressure gradient across the obstruction. This change in murmur intensity can help differentiate HCM from other causes of systolic murmurs, such as ventricular septal defect and mitral regurgitation.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve occurs in acute rheumatic fever (RF), which is typically preceded by a group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Acute RF could lead to significant mitral regurgitation, manifesting as exercise intolerance. However, mitral regurgitation would cause a pansystolic murmur rather than a systolic ejection murmur, and ECG findings in acute rheumatic fever include different degrees of atrioventricular block rather than the changes seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient has not had a recent GAS infection and has had no other features of rheumatic fever.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve occurs secondary to aortic valve stenosis (AS). Patients can present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, while examination may reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur and ECG may show evidence of compensatory left ventricular hypertrophy. However, calcific AS is a disease seen in advanced age. Even though individuals with an anatomically abnormal (unicuspid or bicuspid) valve can develop calcific AS one or two decades earlier than those with a normal (tricuspid) valve, this 25-year-old patient is too young to have developed calcific AS. Furthermore, there is no hereditary component to this disease.
questions.hint: This young man has a family history of sudden cardiac death and has just experienced exertional syncope. He has a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the apex and left lower sternal border as well as an S4.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing during soccer practice. The patient appears well. His pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. Rapid squatting decreases the intensity of the patient's auscultation finding. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
Video

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve
Eccentric dilatation of the left ventricle

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) manifests with an area of increased left ventricular wall thickness that is typically asymmetrical and involves the septum or anterolateral LV wall. Along with mitral valve and papillary muscle abnormalities, septal hypertrophy can lead to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, resulting in exertional syncope and systolic ejection murmur, both of which are seen in this patient. The intensity of the murmur associated with HCM decreases with maneuvers that increase venous return (e.g., rapid squatting) because they increase preload, which in turn decreases the pressure gradient across the obstruction. This change in murmur intensity can help differentiate HCM from other causes of systolic murmurs, such as ventricular septal defect and mitral regurgitation.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve occurs in acute rheumatic fever (RF), which is typically preceded by a group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Acute RF could lead to significant mitral regurgitation, manifesting as exercise intolerance. However, mitral regurgitation would cause a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex rather than a systolic ejection murmur. Rapid squatting would result in an increased, not decreased, intensity of the murmur associated with mitral regurgitation. Furthermore, this patient has not had a recent GAS infection and has had no other features of RF.

C) INCORRECT:

Significant dilatation of the left ventricle is characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy. While patients with dilated cardiomyopathy may present with exertional dyspnea from heart failure, they are less likely to experience exertional syncope. Examination may reveal an S3 and/or a pansystolic murmur of secondary mitral regurgitation heard best at the apex due to LV dilatation. A prominent systolic ejection murmur, as seen in this patient, would not be expected. Furthermore, rapid squatting would result in an increased, not decreased, intensity of the murmur associated with mitral regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve occurs secondary to aortic valve stenosis (AS). Patients can present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, and examination may reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur, as seen here. However, an AS murmur is heard best at the right upper sternal border, not the left sternal border. In addition, calcific AS is a disease usually seen in advanced age. Even though individuals with an anatomically abnormal (unicuspid or bicuspid) valve can develop calcific AS one or two decades earlier than those with a normal (tricuspid) valve, this 26-year-old patient is most likely too young to have developed calcific AS.

E) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the aortic root occurs in individuals with connective tissue syndromes (e.g., Marfan syndrome), a bicuspid aortic valve, and aortic dissection. Significant dilatation of the aortic annulus can lead to aortic regurgitation, which results in a decrescendo diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border, in contrast to the systolic ejection murmur seen here. Furthermore, this patient's condition is not associated with aortic root dilation.
questions.hint: This young man has just experienced exertional syncope. He has a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border as well as a fourth heart sound (S4).

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after having been hit by a car while riding his bicycle. He was not wearing a helmet. Despite appropriate life-saving measures, he dies 2 hours later because of a severe intracranial hemorrhage. Autopsy of the heart shows general thickening of the left ventricular wall with narrowing of the ventricular chamber. Which of the following conditions is the most likely underlying cause of the described cardiac changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation causes backflow of blood into the left ventricle during diastole, resulting in an increased preload. The increased blood volume in the left ventricle triggers myocardial remodeling, specifically the addition of sarcomeres in series. This results in eccentric (not concentric) hypertrophy, eventually leading to dilated cardiomyopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic heavy drinking can result in dilated cardiomyopathy, which is caused by eccentric ventricular hypertrophy, not the concentric ventricular hypertrophy seen in this patient. The pathogenesis of alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy is not entirely understood, but it occurs in part due to the direct toxic effects of alcohol and its metabolites (e.g., acetaldehyde) on myocytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Myocardial ischemia is the cause of ischemic cardiomyopathy, which results in the replacement of the myocytes with scar tissue. The lack of contractile tissue in myocardial fibrosis causes a systolic impairment, which results in a reduced ejection fraction (EF). Cardiac preload is increased to compensate for the reduced EF (via the Frank Starling mechanism), which results in sarcomeres being duplicated in series and eccentric ventricular hypertrophy.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic hypertension is the most common cause of concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Hypertension causes increased afterload, resulting in elevated left ventricular wall stress. When this increased wall stress is sustained, e.g., in chronic hypertension, gene expression is altered in muscle cells, leading to an increased number of sarcomeres. When responding to increased afterload, sarcomeres will duplicate in parallel, resulting in concentric hypertrophy and the thickened ventricular wall seen in this patient. A sustained increase in preload, on the other hand, will result in eccentric hypertrophy with an associated dilation of the ventricular chamber.

Other causes of concentric left ventricular hypertrophy are aortic valve stenosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis is associated with both dilated and restrictive cardiomyopathy. During the early stages of cardiac hemochromatosis, a restrictive pattern of left ventricular filling is seen due to iron deposition in cardiac muscle. As the disease progresses, systolic dysfunction occurs, which leads to dilated cardiomyopathy (due to eccentric hypertrophy). However, cardiac hemochromatosis does not result in concentric ventricular hypertrophy.

F) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis can manifest with either dilated or restrictive cardiomyopathy, both of which are due to granulomatous infiltration of the cardiac myocardium. Clinical features of cardiac sarcoidosis depend on the degree of myocardial granulomatous infiltration. Cardiac sarcoidosis is most commonly asymptomatic but can also result in arrhythmias and conduction defects. Cardiac sarcoidosis does not cause concentric ventricular hypertrophy.
questions.hint: Thickening of the ventricular wall with narrowing of the ventricular chamber is caused by concentric ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he had a cardiac arrest. He was playing soccer with his friends at school when he suddenly collapsed on the field. A teacher who witnessed the incident successfully performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation and called the ambulance. The patient has no history of serious illness. His uncle died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 35. On arrival, he appears exhausted. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is heard best at the apex and left lower sternal border, and an S4 gallop. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of premature death in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a cardiac pacemaker may be considered in symptomatic patients with HOCM who have not responded to other pharmacological and nonpharmacological treatment options. Although cardiac pacing can provide symptomatic relief in these patients, it does not decrease their risk of premature death. A different treatment should be attempted in this patient before considering cardiac pacing.

B) INCORRECT:

Nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), including verapamil, can be used as second-line agents for the management of symptomatic HOCM to provide heart rate control, which allows for longer diastole and increased diastolic filling. However, these agents are not known to reduce the risk of premature death in patients with HOCM. In addition, if severe LVOTO is also present, nondihydropyridine CCBs should be used with caution because their marked vasodilatory effects can increase the degree of LVOTO and worsen these patients' symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Placement of an automated implantable cardioverter defibrillator (AICD) is the best method to prevent sudden cardiac death (SCD) in patients with HOCM and a history of sudden cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia. Other indications for AICD placement in patients with HOCM include a positive family history of SCD in a close relative ≤ 50 years of age, syncope of unknown cause, left ventricular (LV) wall thickness ≥ 30 mm, LV apical aneurysms, and LV systolic dysfunction. Patients with HOCM who are not in any of these categories still require risk stratification for AICD placement because of the high risk of SCD associated with this condition.

Beta blockers are the first-line therapy for the symptomatic treatment of patients with HOCM. Other therapy options include nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, septal myectomy, and cardiac pacemaker. High-dose diuretics, spironolactone, and digoxin should generally be avoided. It is important to note that these treatment options are not known to reduce the risk of premature death in patients with HOCM.

D) INCORRECT:

Septal myectomy is an effective treatment option for patients with symptomatic HOCM who have not responded to medical treatment. Although septal myectomy can provide symptomatic relief in these patients, it does not decrease their risk of premature death. A different treatment should be attempted in this patient before surgery is considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics, including furosemide, may be considered in a patient with symptomatic HOCM without LVOTO who has not responded to first-line treatment. However, in patients like this one with HOCM and significant LVOTO, high-dose diuretics should be avoided because they can increase the degree of outflow obstruction by reducing the preload. In addition, loop diuretics are not known to reduce the risk of premature death in patients with HOCM.
questions.hint: This patient's sudden cardiac arrest after physical activity is most likely due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO). His family history (sudden cardiac death in a young relative) and physical examination findings (systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the apex, S4 gallop) are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man who was diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 2 years ago presents for follow-up. He has been treated with a beta-blocker and has not had any symptoms of chest pain, shortness of breath, or presyncope; he does not participate in contact sports.
His father and older brother also had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; both died suddenly in their forties.
On examination, the patient has a blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while he is breathing ambient air. An echocardiogram reveals a septal wall thickness of 3.1 cm. His left ventricular outflow pressure gradient is 30 mm Hg at rest and 50 mm Hg with amyl nitrate provocation.
Which one of the following additional treatments is indicated in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A beta-blocker can be given to asymptomatic patients with HCM, but the clinical value of beta-blocker therapy in this context is unclear. In this patient, the beta-blocker dose should not be increased, as the patient’s heart rate and blood pressure are well controlled, and he is asymptomatic.

B) INCORRECT:

The addition of disopyramide is not recommended in an asymptomatic patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Septal myotomy involves a simple incision of the septal muscle. In the treatment of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, septal myectomy has replaced septal myotomy and is only indicated for patients with severe symptoms due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Septal myectomy is not recommended in an asymptomatic patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

D) CORRECT:

The annual risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD) in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is about 5%. Therefore, an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) can play an important role in this population.

Not all patients with HCM benefit from an ICD, so they should be assessed for major SCD risk factors, such as a history of cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation, spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia, or a family history of SCD in at least two first-degree relatives who had HCM. Minor risk factors include unexplained syncope (2 episodes in the past year), septal wall thickness > 3 cm, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, a high-risk genetic defect, an abnormal blood-pressure response with exercise, and left ventricular outflow obstruction > 30 mm Hg.

Many institutions insert an ICD for one or more major SCD risk factors or three or more minor risk factors. This patient has one major and two minor SCD risk factors and thus should be considered for an ICD.

Key learning point: The indications for an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are a history of cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation, spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia, or a family history of sudden cardiac death in at least two first-degree relatives who had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Septal ablation is only indicated for patients with severe symptoms due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. This procedure is not recommended in an asymptomatic patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman reports several episodes of syncope while engaged in strenuous activity. The episodes have increased in frequency during the past year. She also reports worsening dyspnea on exertion when walking up two flights of stairs.
Her blood pressure is 125/76 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 83 beats per minute. A 3/6 harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the left lower sternal border becomes louder with the Valsalva maneuver.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a soft systolic murmur can be heard in patients with an atrial septal defect related to increased flow across the pulmonary valve, the characteristic examination finding is a fixed, split second heart sound. A systolic flow murmur, if present, would decrease in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver.

B) INCORRECT:

The classic cardiac examination finding in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a systolic ejection murmur that becomes louder with maneuvers that decrease venous return (i.e., preload), such as the Valsalva maneuver or standing. That finding is in contrast to the systolic murmur that is characteristic of aortic or pulmonary stenosis, which becomes softer with decreased preload.

C) INCORRECT:

A classic ventricular septal defect murmur is holosystolic and does not change in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. Atrial septal defect and ventricular septal defect are rarely associated with syncope unless the patient has severe pulmonary hypertension related to Eisenmenger syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

The classic cardiac examination finding in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a systolic ejection murmur that becomes louder with maneuvers that decrease venous return (i.e., preload), such as the Valsalva maneuver or standing. That finding is in contrast to the systolic murmur that is characteristic of aortic or pulmonary stenosis, which becomes softer with decreased preload.

E) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a genetic disorder resulting in significant hypertrophy without an identifiable cause. Dyspnea on exertion, angina, syncope, and elevated risk for sudden cardiac death are features of HCM. Up to 75% of patients with HCM have left ventricular outflow tract obstruction either at rest or with physical exertion. The classic cardiac examination finding in these individuals is a systolic ejection murmur that becomes louder with maneuvers that decrease venous return (i.e., preload), such as the Valsalva maneuver or standing. That finding is in contrast to the systolic murmur that is characteristic of aortic or pulmonary stenosis, which becomes softer with decreased preload.

Key learning point: A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that becomes louder with the Valsalva maneuver is most consistent with a diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A previously asymptomatic, 25-year-old man with no significant medical history is evaluated following an episode of syncope that occurred while he was playing basketball and that was preceded only by brief lightheadedness. He regained consciousness spontaneously after approximately 20 seconds. Vital signs and physical examination are normal, except for the cardiac evaluation, which reveals a normal rate and rhythm with a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. An echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular systolic function, no significant valvular abnormalities, and severe septal hypertrophy, with a measured thickness of 3.2 cm.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with digoxin and other positive inotropes should be avoided in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Septal myectomy is the most established remedy for obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy when symptoms of heart failure become refractory to optimal medical treatment, but it may not prevent sudden cardiac death.

C) INCORRECT:

Placement of a Holter monitor or a 30-day event monitor is not appropriate in a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy patient already considered to be at high risk for sudden cardiac death.

D) CORRECT:

An episode of recent unexplained syncope in a patient with severe septal hypertrophy is an indication for placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator to reduce the risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD). SCD risk factors in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) include recent unexplained syncope, left ventricular wall thickness ≥30 mm, family history of HCM and SCD, age <30 with evidence of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, and an abnormal blood-pressure response (i.e., a decrease) during stress testing. This patient is at high risk for SCD, so he does not require documentation of a ventricular arrhythmia before implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement.

Key learning point: The most appropriate prophylaxis to prevent sudden cardiac death in a patient with recent unexplained syncope and severe septal hypertrophy from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

E) INCORRECT:

Placement of a Holter monitor or a 30-day event monitor is not appropriate in a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy patient already considered to be at high risk for sudden cardiac death.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents for a preparticipation physical before soccer season. A thorough history is unremarkable; there is no family history of early cardiac disease or sudden cardiac death. He appears well, and his vital signs are normal.
A harsh crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border. There are no clicks, gallops, or palpable thrill. The intensity of the murmur increases with the Valsalva maneuver and does not appear to radiate to the neck.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis creates a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the right sternal border and that radiates to the neck. The Valsalva maneuver reduces the intensity of the murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral-valve prolapse is characterized by a late systolic murmur preceded by a click, and the Valsalva maneuver increases the murmur.

C) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the most common cause of sudden cardiac death among athletes, is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder. Because HCM is often asymptomatic until sudden cardiac death, the cardiac portion of a preparticipation sports physical is intended to identify people who are at increased risk. In addition to screening questions to assess family and personal history of cardiac disease, a thorough cardiac physical examination is essential.

The murmur associated with HCM is related to turbulent blood flow through the asymmetric hypertrophic left ventricle during systole. On auscultation, the murmur is midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo, located over the left sternal border. The murmur of HCM increases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload, such as the Valsalva maneuver or moving to a standing position.

Key learning point: A midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is located over the left sternal border and increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver is most consistent with a diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

A bicuspid aortic valve can lead to aortic stenosis and/or aortic regurgitation, which would produce an early diastolic blowing murmur at the left sternal border.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect produces a pansystolic murmur at the left sternal border and a diastolic murmur related to the flow of blood from the left to the right side of the heart during diastole.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents for a preparticipation physical before soccer season. A thorough history is unremarkable; there is no family history of early cardiac disease or sudden cardiac death. He appears well and is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are normal.
A harsh crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border. There are no clicks, gallops, or palpable thrill. The intensity of the murmur increases with the Valsalva maneuver and does not appear to radiate to the neck.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral-valve prolapse is characterized by a late systolic murmur preceded by a click, and the Valsalva maneuver increases the murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis creates a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the right sternal border and that radiates to the neck. The Valsalva maneuver reduces the intensity of the murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

A bicuspid aortic valve results in mild to moderate aortic regurgitation and produces an early diastolic blowing murmur at the left sternal border.

D) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the most common cause of sudden cardiac death among athletes, is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder. Because HCM is often asymptomatic until sudden cardiac death, the cardiac portion of a preparticipation sports physical is intended to identify people who are at increased risk. In addition to screening questions to assess family and personal history of cardiac disease, a thorough cardiac physical examination is essential.

The murmur associated with HCM is related to turbulent blood flow through the asymmetric hypertrophic left ventricle during systole. On auscultation, the murmur is midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo, located over the left sternal border. The murmur of HCM increases in intensity with maneuvers that decrease preload, such as the Valsalva maneuver or moving to a standing position.

Key learning point: A midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is located over the left sternal border and increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver is most consistent with a diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect produces a pansystolic murmur at the left sternal border and a diastolic murmur related to the flow of blood from the left to the right side of the heart during diastole.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy with no significant medical history is evaluated following an episode of syncope that occurred while he was playing basketball and that was preceded only by brief lightheadedness. He regained consciousness spontaneously after approximately 20 seconds.
Vital signs and physical examination are normal, with the exception of a 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo murmur that was louder with a handgrip maneuver and softer with squatting. An echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular systolic function, no significant valvular abnormalities, and severe septal hypertrophy, with a measured thickness of 3.2 cm.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with digoxin and other positive inotropes should be avoided in patients with HCM.

B) INCORRECT:

Placement of a Holter monitor or a 30-day event monitor is not appropriate in an HCM patient already considered to be at high risk for SCD.

C) INCORRECT:

Placement of a Holter monitor or a 30-day event monitor is not appropriate in an HCM patient already considered to be at high risk for SCD.

D) INCORRECT:

Septal myectomy is the most established remedy for obstructive HCM when symptoms of heart failure become refractory to optimal medical treatment, but it may not prevent SCD.

E) CORRECT:

An episode of recent unexplained syncope in a patient with severe septal hypertrophy is an indication for placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator to reduce the risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD). SCD risk factors in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) include recent unexplained syncope, left ventricular wall thickness ≥30 mm, family history of HCM and SCD, age <30 with evidence of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, and an abnormal blood-pressure response (i.e., a decrease) during stress testing. This patient is at high risk for SCD, so he does not require documentation of a ventricular arrhythmia before implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement.

Key learning point: The most appropriate prophylaxis to prevent sudden cardiac death in a patient with recent unexplained syncope and severe septal hypertrophy from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

questions.text:
A healthy 15-year-old boy presents for a sports preparticipation evaluation. His father was recently diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy after a murmur was heard during a routine physical examination. There is no other known family history of cardiac disease or unexplained sudden cardiac death. The patient is very active physically and has no personal history of syncope or chest pain with exercise.
His electrocardiogram and echocardiogram findings are normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Referral for placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator
Repeat screening echocardiography in 3 to 5 years
Genetic testing of the father, followed by targeted genetic testing of the patient

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activity restriction in patients with HCM is based on multiple historical and clinical factors, including family history of sudden cardiac death, previous symptoms of chest pain or syncope with exercise, abnormal echocardiographic findings, and abnormal results on ambulatory cardiac monitoring and exercise testing. Restriction from competitive sports would be premature in a patient in whom HCM has not yet been identified.

B) INCORRECT:

Placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is recommended for patients with HCM who are thought to be at highest risk for sudden cardiac death. Risk factors that should prompt consideration of ICD placement include a family history of sudden cardiac death, a personal history of previous cardiac arrest, sustained or nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, unexplained syncope, massive hypertrophy, and an abnormal blood-pressure response to exercise. This patient has no indication for placement of an ICD at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating echocardiographic screening every 3 to 5 years in this patient would not be appropriate at this time. Genetic testing should be the first step; if that is not possible or not available, echocardiograms should be repeated every 1 to 2 years in this age group, not every 3 to 5 years.

D) CORRECT:

Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant genetic condition, which means that an affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the disease-causing gene to his or her offspring. The disorder is highly penetrant; people who carry the affected gene have a nearly 95% chance of experiencing manifestations of the disease.
